messages.text:
For reference, here's what I communicated to Darren:

```Hi Darren, 

Here are the environments we need for this project:

Firebase: Blaze Plan (this should be sufficient at cutting down the response time from our side. We can always upgrade this later, if your production needs turn out to be heavier)
Render: Standard Plan (we will run Express JS off of this, which will host the Node.js instance)
OpenAI: Pay-As-You-Go (this we can change later, once we get a better understanding of your actual usage volume in production)

I looked through all the documents. Since we have moved away from the AI acting as a lawyer, and more into the role of being a paralegal, I think the documents will not pose much of a challenge. The references and indices will be problematic based on the POC design, but the corpus of the knowledge should be capturable without a lot of additional advanced engineering from our end. As for the references and indices, we can solve that as a v2 feature. They require a separate approach, though not unachievable. 

Note that we will structure this project's components as decentralized as possible, so we can swap individual pieces out later. I think OpenAI has lost its edge, and will likely continue to lose ground for some time. Starting with the mess that's GPT-5, those guys have been more about capturing media attention than doing real science, and now it seems like they are about to pay for it. So, we will keep our eyes peeled, and will switch away from OpenAI if it has become clear that a superior AI implementation is available and stable.

Aris```

messages.text:
*ARA Project – Architecture & Setup (POC)*
• Firestore: Database only (not a server)
• Backend: Node/Express hosted on Render *(access required)*
• Frontend: React app hosted as a static site (Firebase Hosting or equivalent)
• GitHub: Repos under DevPixel SEG 
• OpenAI: Accessed only via backend; keys stored in Render env vars *(access required)*
• Environment: Single POC environment only
• Branding & Domain: Out of scope for POC
*Next steps today*
• Clone the DevPixel website codebase and clean up unnecessary logic
• Once Render and OpenAI access is received, configurations will be updated.

1. Go to the IAM Console <https://console.cloud.google.com/>
2. Navigate to the Google Cloud IAM page.
3. Locate User.
4. Click the edit (pencil) icon related to user and add one of the following roles.

Cloud Datastore Owner: Full access to Firestore and indexes. (OR)
Firebase Admin: Full access to all Firebase services, including Firestore.

Firebase Admin: Full access to all Firebase services, including Firestore.

messages.text:
*<@U02JFCNHKHB>, Response rehydration is handled directly by OpenAI’s Response API.*
 When a user submits a query, the Response API automatically performs *semantic retrieval of the top-K relevant chunks from the attached vector store*.
These retrieved chunks are used internally by OpenAI as grounding context to *rehydrate the response*—that is, to reconstruct a complete, context-aware answer based on our stored documents.
On the UI, the final response returned by OpenAI is rendered using a React Markdown library for clean and readable presentation.

<@U02JFCNHKHB>, I apologize for not using the *Retrieval API* for fetching *top-K results* as suggested.
While reviewing the requirement from a broader perspective, I mainly focused on the *Chat Completions API, Assistants API, and Responses API*, which handle retrieval, grounding, and response generation internally when used with a vector store. Because of this, I did not explicitly evaluate or propose the Retrieval API approach at that time.
I should have communicated this distinction earlier, and I apologize for the oversight. This was a mistake on my part—I missed the Retrieval API while researching the available approaches online.

messages.text:
This is the critical step for this project. 

We will initially control the context size by manually splitting the chapter into smaller parts. We are breaking the chapter apart by sections right now, but certain sections might need to be broken down even more. 

But eventually, we will need to control the rehydration:

1. If the scores are too low, we need to send some standard "I don't know" context instead. 
2. If the matched file is too big or the matched chunk is leaning too much towards the beginning or the end, we would need to return its neighbors strategically to get usable results. 
3. Finally, if the matched chunk needs a table from the appendix, we would need to pull that as part of the rehydration as well.

messages.text:
The problem becomes complicated when you get several matches all matching different parts of the document. This is when hydration control becomes absolutely critical. 

1. Try to formulate matching ranges (9.1-3) and process the entire range at once
2. First summarize a matched section, and then use the summary as the context
For the second approach, you should create summaries for each document uploaded, and stored together in firebase. This would make the rehydration both faster and also more consistent

messages.text:
<@U02JFCNHKHB> A thought, since the file splitting is already a manual and controlled step, we're considering adding a simple linear sequence index (1, 2, 3, …) to each chunk as an additional field. The goal is to make previous/next neighbor selection fully deterministic and easier to reason about at runtime, especially when implementing neighbor expansion and range-based hydration logic.

We’ll still retain the section identifiers (e.g., 6.1, 6.1.1, 6.1.3) to preserve the legal hierarchy and semantic meaning, which we’ll continue to use for parent–child relationships. The sequence index would purely serve as a navigation aid, not as a replacement for section structure.

Summary-first was brought up when the document matched is too big. 

First, use the whole matched document (already split manually)

If that's too big, select the full parent section. So, if matched on 6.1.2, pull the entire 6.1 as context. 

If that's still too big, pull the neighbors. For 6.1.2, it would be 6.1.1 and 6.1.3.

If that's STILL too big, then summarize 6.1 and send together with the full text of 6.1.2.

*<@UM3V8V1NK>*
 Yesterday I implemented the neighbor-inclusion logic (order-1, order, order+1) for rehydration. That part is working correctly.
However, the chunks that were previously uploaded are still very large. Because of this, when multiple matches and their neighbors are pulled together, the total context quickly exceeds the LLM size limit.
To make the neighbor and range-based rehydration effective, we now need to *re-upload the content as smaller, more granular chunks* . This will allow us to include neighbors and control context size properly without hitting token limits.

<@U08Q13RK6P4> // STEP 1: Try full matched document
    context = getFullDocument(doc)

    if (context).length < MAX_CONTEXT_TOKENS:
        return context

// STEP 2: Try full parent section (6.1)
    parentSection = getSection(doc, parentId)

    if (parentSection).length < MAX_CONTEXT_TOKENS:
        return parentSection

// STEP 3: Try neighbors (6.1.1 + 6.1.2 + 6.1.3)
    neighbors = getNeighborSections(doc, sectionId)
    context = concatenate(neighbors)

    if (context).length < MAX_CONTEXT_TOKENS:
        return context

// STEP 4: Summary-first fallback
    summary = getSummary(doc, parentId)


    context = concatenate(summary, matchedText)

    return context

messages.text:
Keep in mind that: every time you upload something, you need to remove the previous versions. 

In other words, each text part must be unique. So, if you break down 6.1 to 6.1.1, 6.1.2... you need to remove 6.1 completely when uploading the parts individually. 

If you don't do that, you will end up with very problematic matches, starting with duplicated and misaligning chunks. It can eventually lead to misinterpretations due to misaligning chunks being interpreted together as a coherent context.

messages.text: <@U02JFCNHKHB> Apologies for the confusion, we're splitting documents strictly by section hierarchy, not by page count or arbitrary size. We start at section level (e.g., 6.1, 6.2) and only go one level deeper (6.1.1, 6.1.2, etc.) when a section is too large.

elements.text: Apologies for the confusion, we're splitting documents strictly by section hierarchy, not by page count or arbitrary size. We start at section level (e.g., 6.1, 6.2) and only go one level deeper (6.1.1, 6.1.2, etc.) when a section is too large.

messages.text:
Just for background information purposes, the reason why this division is necessary is:

1. The latest technology is not enough to correctly distinguish document structure, especially when the document is long and/or the structure is not programmatically clear (think HTML structure). Because of this, all current AI cannot correctly rehydrate without introducing irrelevant parts. We are manually limiting the range to mitigate this limitation.
2. Chunking needs continuity. This means every chunk must overlap significantly with the neighboring chunks. But how much to overlap is a constantly evolving field that still needs a lot of research. If we do this manually, it is extremely unlikely that we will produce a better result than the algorithmic ones. On top of that, when new research comes out, the automated ones will get immediately updated, but we will be stuck with our outdated, manually created version.

If we do this manually, it is extremely unlikely that we will produce a better result than the algorithmic ones. messages.text:
<@U02JFCNHKHB> So far, our neighboring logic has been defined assuming smaller chunk documents, where before and after simply meant retrieving the previous and next chunk documents. In the current case, the section itself is very large (e.g., Chapter 6, Section III, Part D ~104 pages), and the neighboring logic would therefore operate within this large section, not across multiple small chunk documents.

That means rehydration would need to locate the matched content within this section and pull a larger context window before and after that match from the same document. If this is the intended approach, could you advise on how we should define those boundaries safely?

Ok. That's actually very good.

Expand that to all the chunks with a score above 0.5. The reason is all 5 might point to the exact document, since the document slices are so large. We will adjust that score later. 0.5 should work for now.

For example, the question "When do I need to distribute the 402f notice?" should match Part C and Part D. But since Part C is so big, top 5 will never get to Part D. Without Part D, the bot can only respond with "I don't have that information", even though Part D gives the exact answer.

Summary-first was brought up when the document matched is too big. 

First, use the whole matched document (already split manually)

If that's too big, select the full parent section. So, if matched on 6.1.2, pull the entire 6.1 as context.

If that's STILL too big, then summarize 6.1 and send together with the full text of 6.1.2.

messages.text:
Next Priority: Query Construction

"Query Construction" (QC) means we 1) take in what the user has entered and 2) build a new query out of it.

Right now, we are simply sending the query into the LLM as is. While it produces usable results, it is far from good quality. This is the sibling of rehydration.

Conceptually, this is what needs to happen:

1. User enters inquiry
2. We query the LLM for any unclear concepts within the inquiry
3. We send concepts to vector DB
4. We rehydrate the matches
5. We query the LLM with the inquiry and the matches, asking it to rebuilt the inquiry for better clarity
6. We send the NEW inquiry to vector DB and do what we do today
We need manual control over all the steps above. The rehydration of the matches in Step 4 is not the same as the one for the actual inquiry.

To build this out, we need to do it in stages. For the first stage, do this:

1. (existing) User enters inquiry
2. (new) Query the LLM for any unclear concepts within the inquiry
3. (existing) Send the original inquiry to vector DB and do what we do today
Once this is done, we can start building out the rest.

Need a timeline for this. <@UM3V8V1NK>

<@U02JFCNHKHB> Please find the first stage deliverable timeline.

*Query Construction – Phase 1: Unclear Concept Detection*
Estimated Effort: 6–8 hours
Delivery: 29 January 26
Resource: Soheb

*Scope*
 Build the first QC stage to determine whether a user query is clear before retrieval.

*What’s Included*
• LLM-based classification: CLEAR / UNCLEAR
    ◦ Extract only unclear words or phrases verbatim from the query
    ◦ Return strict JSON only:
`{ "isClear": true|false, "concepts": [] }`
    ◦ Backend logging for inputs, outputs, and debugging
    ◦ Validation using real production queries
*Out of Scope*
    ◦ Query rewriting or clarification
    ◦ Vector DB lookup or rehydration logic

messages.text:
<@U02JFCNHKHB>
I tested this with a question whose answer depends on two consecutive chunks.
*Current behavior:*
• We take unique matched chunks (score ≥ threshold)
• They are processed in ascending order
• For each matched chunk, we add:
Order − 1 → PREV_LAST (last 3000 chars)
Order → CURR_FULL (entire matched chunk)
Order + 1 → NEXT_FIRST (first 3000 chars)
*Issue observed:*
• When matched chunks are consecutive, this approach causes overlapping context.
• Example:
Order 2 matched → includes Order 1 (prev) and Order 3 (next)
Order 3 matched → includes Order 2 (prev) and Order 4 (next)
• Result: Orders 2 and 3 are duplicated in the final context.

When matched chunks are consecutive, can I handle it like this to *avoid overlapping context*?
```Order 1 → PREV_LAST (last 3000 chars)
Order 2 → CURR_FULL (matched)
Order 3 → CURR_FULL (matched)
Order 4 → NEXT_FIRST (first 3000 chars)```

• Example:

When matched chunks are consecutive, can I handle it like this to
avoid overlapping context

Order 1 → PREV_LAST (last 3000 chars)
Order 2 → CURR_FULL (matched)
Order 3 → CURR_FULL (matched)
Order 4 → NEXT_FIRST (first 3000 chars)

messages.text: Yes, we need to specifically handle this. We can take this a step further. As long as two chunks are within X distance, we can combine them. When this happens, it usually means the entire section is relevant. But since we can't send the entire file, the least we can do is combine the closely matched ones.

messages.text:
*<@UM3V8V1NK>,*
Regarding the issue with *Chapter 6 Section VII Part D.6.docx* missing, we have two possible ways to resolve it:
1. *Option 1: Delete and Upload Properly*
We can delete the existing chunks for *Chapter 6 Section VII Part D.5* and re-upload them correctly. This would fix the issue, but it requires removing and uploading other chunks.
2. *Option 2: Insert Missing Chunk*
Alternatively, we can give users an *insert chunk* option. If they miss a chunk, they only need to upload the missed chunk without needing to delete others.
*Backend Handling*: When the chunk is uploaded, we need to handle the order numbers. The order numbers for the chunks after the uploaded one need to be shifted +1 to accommodate the new chunk. Also, we need to specify at which order number the chunk should be inserted.
